Award.AwardTitle: Unveiling Nucleation Mechanisms of Natural Gas Hydrates Under Realistic Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural gas hydrates represent both a potential source of energy--as much as twice of all other fossil fuels combined--and a fouling and safety problem, when they accumulate inside oil and gas pipelines. An understanding of how gas hydrates form, specifically at the nucleation stage, will have an impact on energy storage, transport, and possibly CO2 sequestration. This proposal will use a state of the art forward flux sampling (FFS) technique to enhance statistical sampling of rare nucleation events that are often missed by direct molecular dynamics simulations, thus potentially getting a better understanding of hydrate formation.

A better understanding of how gas hydrates are formed, especially at the nucleation stage, will have an impact on both energy storage and transport safety of gas and oil pipelines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Occurring naturally, natural gas hydrates store vast amount of energy—as much as twice of all other fossil fuels combined, while accumulating inside oil and gas pipelines, these ice-like crystals plug transmission lines, posing sever safety issue to the oil and gas industry. An understanding of the nucleation mechanism at the molecular level is the key to controlling and employing the formation of hydrates. This mechanism remains poorly understood. The research objective of this project is to apply an advanced sampling method combined with large-scale molecular simulations to investigate the initial step of natural gas hydrates formation under or close to realistic conditions.

 

Intellectual Merit: Probing hydrate nucleation at the molecular level has been a major challenge in both experiment and theory. In particular, current theoretical studies have not allowed acquiring nucleation details 1) with sufficient statistical sampling or 2) under realistic conditions. These critical limitations impede our understanding and exploitation of gas hydrates. To overcome these limits, we developed a new computational strategy by integrating our designed order parameter, half cage order parameter, with the forward flux sampling method.

The new computational strategy greatly enhances our capacity for probing the molecular pathways of hydrate formation. Specifically, through the developed approach, we have (1) significantly extended the accessible ranges of thermodynamic conditions in the molecular simulations of hydrate nucleation, (2) incorporated a quantitative and statistical view in understanding hydrate nucleation, and (3) proposed a new hydrate nucleation mechanism. These accomplishments open new opportunities for investigating hydrate nucleation, facilitating new perspectives of hydrate formation, and bridging the gap between theory and experiments.

The project has yielded three published journal papers, one Ph.D. dissertation, seven invited talks including one at the Natural Gas Hydrate Systems Gordon Research Conference, and 16 conference talks.   

 

Broader Impact: A fundamental understanding of hydrates nucleation mechanism at the molecular level enables us to design strategies for controlling the formation rate of gas hydrates according to the application. The immediate benefit of this research is in the areas of gas transportation/storage and flow assurance in the oil industry, as the former requires rapid synthesis of hydrates while the latter struggles to suppress hydrates formation.

Since our developed approach constructs a new paradigm for modeling nucleation in multi-component, non-stoichiometric systems, the method can now be adopted to study nucleation processes of a broader range of materials of interest. As a successful example, we have recently applied the knowledge and insight gained from this project to a different material system, leading to the prediction of new materials: inert gas inorganic clathrates, which are promising materials for opto-electronic and thermoelectric applications.   

To disseminate research into general public, the PI has been participating Science Olympiad, which is a nation-wide, school-based, and extra-curricular science program that embraces the STEM education for students from third grade through high school. Specifically, the PI has been working closely with Virginia Science Olympiad (VASO) that leads the program at the state (Virginia) level that involves over 2000 K-12 students. In 2013, 2014, and 2017, the PI organized the Materials Science event, one of the tournament events of VASO, by composing all the written and lab test materials for both regional and state tournaments and supervising regional tournaments in local high schools. In addition, the PI has also participated the Protein Modeling Event in 2015 and 2016.

The project supported two graduate students and one female undergraduate student. The project has also led to three presentation awards in the GWU SEAS R&D Showcase events, including one award for undergraduate student (2015) and two awards for graduate students (2016 & 2017).
